description.plain:
Shéyaa Bin Abraham-Joseph, known professionally as 21 Savage, was born in the London Borough of Newham on October 22, 1992 to parents of  Dominican and Haitian descent. He and his mother moved to the United States when Savage was seven years old, residing in East Atlanta, Georgia. In June 2005, he briefly returned to the U.K. for his uncle’s funeral before quickly returning to the U.S. less than a month later on an H-4 visa.

Savage first gained musical notoriety after releasing the underground hit “Picky” in November 2014. The following year, he released three projects: The Slaughter Tape, Free Guwop, and Slaughter King.

After a massive 2015, Savage was included in the 2016 XXL Freshman Class. The cover was revealed on June 13, 2016. A month later, on July 15, 2016, Savage released Savage Mode, a collaborative EP with Metro Boomin.

On July 7, 2017, Savage released his debut studio album, Issa Album. Less than four months later, on October 31, 2017, he released Without Warning, a collaborative album with Offset and Metro.

On December 21, 2018, Savage released his sophomore studio album, i am > i was.

On February 3, 2019, Savage was arrested by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) for overstaying his visa, which initially expired in 2006. Before that, in 2017, Savage applied for a US visa so that he could remain in the United States. He was released on bond nine days later.

On October 2, 2020, 21 Savage and Metro Boomin reunited for their second collaborative album, SAVAGE MODE II.

Shéyaa Bin Abraham-Joseph, known professionally as 21 Savage, was born in the London Borough of Newham on October 22, 1992 to parents of  Dominican and Haitian descent. He and his mother moved to the United States when Savage was seven years old, residing in East Atlanta, Georgia. In June 2005, he briefly returned to the U.K. for his uncle’s funeral before quickly returning to the U.S. less than a month later on an H-4 visa.

Savage first gained musical notoriety after releasing the underground hit “Picky” in November 2014. The following year, he released three projects: The Slaughter Tape, Free Guwop, and Slaughter King.

After a massive 2015, Savage was included in the 2016 XXL Freshman Class. The cover was revealed on June 13, 2016. A month later, on July 15, 2016, Savage released Savage Mode, a collaborative EP with Metro Boomin.

On July 7, 2017, Savage released his debut studio album, Issa Album. Less than four months later, on October 31, 2017, he released Without Warning, a collaborative album with Offset and Metro.

On December 21, 2018, Savage released his sophomore studio album, i am > i was.

On February 3, 2019, Savage was arrested by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) for overstaying his visa, which initially expired in 2006. Before that, in 2017, Savage applied for a US visa so that he could remain in the United States. He was released on bond nine days later.

On October 2, 2020, 21 Savage and Metro Boomin reunited for their second collaborative album, SAVAGE MODE II.

songs.title: Bank Account

description.plain:
“Bank Account” sees 21 Savage rapping about his wealth amongst other things over a dark beat produced by Metro Boomin and 21 Savage himself.

The track samples Coleridge-Taylor Perkinson’s 1974 song “Flashbulbs,” a sample also used on Travis Scott’s “Oh My Dis Side.”

On the 10th of November the music video was released, starring comedian Mike Epps and directed by Matt Swinsky.

songs.title: ​a lot

description.plain:
On the introspective introduction to his sophomore studio album, 21 Savage raps about having “a lot” of blessings and curses in his life. Savage also reflects on his tumultuous upbringing, his dangerous lifestyle, and the pain and loss he has suffered.

Savage calls on J. Cole to assist him on the track. In his verse, Cole reflects on his career, comments on the state of the music industry, and offers advice to other artists and athletes.

The song reached heightened popularity about a month after its release when Savage was arrested by the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) during ATL’s Super Bowl weekend. In the week leading up to his arrest, Savage unveiled an extended version of the track in which he criticizes the U.S.’s immigration policies on the country’s border with Mexico.

songs.title: ​ball w/o you

description.plain: On “ball w/o you,” 21 Savage reflects on multiple past relationships and realizes that he has become disillusioned with love, which he considers artificial. 21 prefers loyalty because he believes it demands a higher level of mutual respect than love.

songs.title: Immortal

description.plain:
On “Immortal,” 21 Savage raps about his murderous tendencies while also name-dropping characters in the Mortal Kombat video game series.

The song was previewed in the Mortal Kombat 11 trailer that was released on December 6, 2018. It was originally speculated to appear on 21’s second studio album, i am > i was, which released two weeks after the trailer. However, this did not occur, and the track’s release date was undetermined.

On August 10, 2019, 21 teased the song’s imminent release, tweeting:
https://twitter.com/21savage/status/1160333306333995008

The track was finally released on Halloween 2019, nearly eleven months after it was first teased.

songs.full_title: ​all my friends by 21 Savage (Ft. Post Malone)
songs.title: ​all my friends

description.plain:
On “all my friends,” 21 Savage and Post Malone reflect on their success and how it has affected their friendships. As they both gained wealth and fame, their respective relationships with envious people deteriorated.

While Post experienced this after his rise to fame, 21 sat down with Rob Markman on ‘For the Record’ and explained that he first began to lose friendships over money when he started getting “street” money, before his rap career.

songs.title: ​asmr

description.plain:
On “asmr,” 21 Savage recalls his whispering flow from November 2018’s “Don’t Come Out the House.”

The song is inspired by ASMR, which stands for ‘autonomous sensory meridian response.’ ASMR describes a feeling of euphoric tingling and relaxation that can come over someone when they hear incredibly quiet sounds, such as whispering, clicking, and chewing. ASMR YouTube channels had a significant rise in popularity in 2018.

21 first previewed this song on November 26, 2018.

songs.title: 4L

description.plain: This track is an ode to 21 Savage and Young Nudy’s shared “4L” gang. They both rap about their murderous lifestyles, specifically naming their many guns and ammunition. They also flex their wealth and sexual endeavors. Savage and Nudy have rapped about 4L throughout their careers.

songs.full_title: Issa by 21 Savage (Ft. Drake & Young Thug)
songs.title: Issa

description.plain:
“Issa” is a catchphrase coined by 21 Savage, first used in his interview with DJ Vlad—“Issa Knife” quickly became slang, and eventually became a meme.

https://twitter.com/21savage/status/826318937151373313

“Issa” was initially only a Young Thug and 21 Savage collaboration when the snippet was released, however, Drake was recruited for his input.

“Issa” was rumored to be called “Petty” or “Kylie Jenner” (in reference to 21’s crush on Kylie) before the official release.

On October 10, 2017, producer Bricks privately uploaded the full song in CDQ on his SoundCloud, but it was only publicly made available in late December. This newer version of the song features Bricks' production tag as well as additional adlibs from Young Thug.

songs.title: Nothin New

description.plain: 21 Savage gets political on “Nothin New,” voicing his frustrations with the system and systematic racism that black people in America face. The title reflects how blasé events like a shooting of a black man or a drop out have become, and how desensitized society has become to it.

songs.title: Famous

description.plain: On “Famous,” the introduction to 21 Savage’s debut studio album Issa Album, he raps about his life and what he has gone through. He starts off the track with the lyrics, “Rags to riches, nigga came from the bottom.” Rags to riches is an expression used to describe a person’s rise from a state of poverty to great wealth.

description.plain:
After releasing his sophomore album on December 21st, 21 Savage surprise-dropped the sequel to “out for the night” three days later on 24 December 2018.

Like its prequel, “out for the night, pt. 2” samples Santana’s “Samba Pa Ti,” but features Billboard-topping rapper Travis Scott. The track is the only addition to the deluxe version of i am > i was.

songs.title: 7 Min Freestyle

description.plain:
Over a menacing instrumental, this freestyle finds 21 discussing “licks, hits” and “sticks” with an aggressive yet somewhat satirical delivery. Featuring an abundance of one-liners – 21 Savage referring to someone as a “shrimp” and insulting another by calling him a “good dude” are common examples of the tongue-in-cheek motives integral to the successful composition of this lengthy banger.

There are some serious moments in the song, however – involving 21’s history, materialism, and violence; accompanied by his distaste for those who depend on external parties for their money.

21 has referred to people as being a “shrimp” multiple times in an earlier freestyle. The term can – by definition be used as a derogatory term toward a “person who is small in stature” and not their crustacean counterparts.

This song was previewed April 26, 2017, via Twitter.

description.plain:
“1.5” is a collaboration between Migos member, Offset, and 21 Savage. The two previously worked together on their collab tape, Without Warning, with Metro Boomin.

The track consists of nonstop financial flexes from them both along with a few mentions of getting with women.

songs.title: ​out for the night

description.plain:
“out for the night” is the fourth track off of 21 Savage’s sophomore album, i am > i was.  The songs contains a sample from Carlos Santana’s 1970 track “Samba Pa Ti”.

A sequel to this track, “out for the night, pt. 2”, was included as the only bonus track to the album’s deluxe edition, with an additional third verse by Travis Scott.

body.plain:
“out for the night” is the fourth track off of 21 Savage’s sophomore album, i am > i was.  The songs contains a sample from Carlos Santana’s 1970 track “Samba Pa Ti”.

A sequel to this track, “out for the night, pt. 2”, was included as the only bonus track to the album’s deluxe edition, with an additional third verse by Travis Scott.

description.plain:
“Whole Lot” culminates the state of 21’s career at this very moment. He is getting the money he earns, but the superstar lifestyle has its problems.

A demo version of the song featuring a verse from Young Thug was leaked on May 30, 2018.

songs.title: FaceTime

description.plain:
“FaceTime” is a unique track on Issa Album as it is a departure from the common themes of the street hustle, tough upbringing, and violence that normally make up 21 Savage songs. Here, he is describing his feelings for a girl and their potential future together.

Days before the release of Issa Album, rumors placed 21 Savage to be dating Amber Rose.

songs.title: ​gun smoke

description.plain:
On “gun smoke,” 21 Savage makes his love and necessity for owning and using firearms crystal clear. Savage discussing themes of having a plethora of weapons is very common within his discography, which he addresses in the song’s first verse:

Savage, why you always rappin' ‘bout guns for? (Straight up)
'Cause, bitch, I fell in love with the gun smoke (Straight up)

While delivering raps about guns, Savage also obligatorily reps his home of East Atlanta and references the viral 2018 dance challenge started by Shiggy to Drake’s 2018 song, “In My Feelings.”

“gun smoke” was first previewed in a trailer exclusive to Spotify for RapCaviar’s i am > i was mini documentary alongside “monster” featuring Childish Gambino.

songs.title: Thug Life

description.plain:
“Thug Life” is an ode to the late hip-hop legend 2Pac. Regarded as one of hip-hop’s best artists of all time, Pac was a notorious gangster and had a prominent tattoo across his stomach that read “Thug Life.”



In 1993, Tupac formed a rap group called Thug Life that consisted of Tupac Shakur, Big Syke, Macadoshis, Stretch, The Rated R, and finally Tupac’s half brother Mopreme. Eventually, the Thug Life caught up with 2Pac on September 7, 1996 and he was shot four times in a drive-by shooting in Las Vegas, Nevada. Six days later, hip-hop lost one of the greatest artists it has ever witnessed.

In addition to referencing 2Pac, “Thug Life,” the sixth track on Issa Album, details 21’s drug-filled beginnings of him hiding crack at his grandmas house, his experience with an unfaithful girl and other dealings that all represent his thug lifestyle.

The song also samples “Giving Him Something He Can Feel,” a classic 90s r&b hit by En Vogue.

songs.title: Close My Eyes

description.plain:
On the third track of his latest album Issa Album, 21 Savage rationalizes his homicidal tendencies and grapples with the consequences of his trapping lifestyle.

There’s a certain game 21 has to play in order to succeed at trapping because to go against that game is suicide. What’s more is that if you aren’t the one murdering, then you are the one getting murdered. Add to that a traumatic childhood which leaves 21 asking God why all his friends had to die growing up, and you’ve got yourself a rationale for killing at least 5 enemy gang members and setting an entire block on fire. Not to mention, wasting the police who come to arrest him and his gang.

As a consequence for all of his actions, 21 sees dead bodies whenever he closes his eyes. He has to live with being the one that made the mothers of his victims cry. He also can’t get any sleep because he’s too high from having to deal with his PTSD.

Yet despite all of his suffering, all of these experiences make him the the last real rapper.

songs.title: Mind Yo Business

description.plain: The sixth track on the Slaughter King album, “Mind Yo Business” alludes to 21’s violent tendencies as evidenced by the graphic lyrics about drugs, guns and killing all over a downright evil and gloomy beat. The song concludes with a flurry of gun shots that artistically wraps up the song and its message, don’t get caught in 21’s way and mind yo business.

songs.title: Secret

description.plain:
“Secret” features 21 Savage taking a major stylistic and venturing into a lighter, sensual R&B track with the help of crooner Summer Walker. The two both talk about keeping their relationship with their significant others a secret, keeping their relationships for themselves and not opening it up to the public.

The song originally appeared online on February 24, 2020, before its official release on April 17, 2020.

songs.full_title: ​​a lot (Video Version) by 21 Savage (Ft. J. Cole)
songs.title: ​​a lot (Video Version)

description.plain:
The music video version of “a lot” follows the same structure of the original song with the addition of a new fourth verse from 21. In that verse, he continues many of the song’s original themes, except for the last few lines, in which he criticizes immigration policies on the United States’ border.

The verse was first discovered on physical versions of 21’s sophomore album, i am > i was, on December 31, 2018. When his management turned in the album for physical copies to be made, they turned in a solo version of the track, likely before Cole’s verse was fully completed. 21 revealed in his For the Record interview with Genius, which was recorded the day before the album dropped, that the song had only fully came together a few days before its release.

21 rapped the solo version of the track during his performance of “a lot” on Jimmy Fallon’s late-night show, which premiered on January 29, 2019. The verse then appeared three days later in the song’s music video, which included all verses. This is when most fans discovered it.

songs.title: 3AM on Glenwood

description.plain:
Continuing Drake’s “Time and Place” series of songs, “3AM on Glenwood” is the second-to-last track on Drizzy and 21 Savage’s collab album, Her Loss.

Surprisingly featuring only 21 Savage vocals, “Glenwood”, refers to Glenwood Road in Delkab County, Georgia, which is where 21 Savage calls home.

Drake’s first Time and Place song came in his debut album, Thank Me Later, in the form of “9AM in Dallas”. Since then, these songs have been a staple in Drake’s catalog, appearing on many notable releases such as 7AM on Bridle Path (Certified Lover Boy), 6PM in New York (If You’re Reading This It’s Too Late), as well as 4PM in Calabasas & 5AM in Toronto (Care Package).

songs.title: Spiral

description.plain:
“Spiral” is 21 Savage’s song from the eponymous 2021 film, the latest instalment in the horror movie series Saw, first premiered on May 14, 2021 after many delays due to the COVID-19 pandemic and its effects on the film and theater industry.

21 Savage’s association with the film was first teased on March 29, 2021, with the movie’s official social media sources posting a promotional picture of the rapper. The song was then previewed in the movie’s second official trailer the day after. On March 30, he announced via Instagram that he would be in charge of the film’s soundtrack.

While past films in the franchise have had a more rock-leaning soundtrack, “Spiral” puts a hip-hop spin on the franchise’s classic theme ”Hello Zepp,” a dramatic piece of incidental music composed by Charlie Clouser for the series' first installment.

songs.full_title: Emergency by 21 Savage (Ft. Gunna & Young Thug)
songs.title: Emergency

description.plain:
21 Savage, Young Thug and Gunna perform on the same song for the first time on “Emergency.” The song is produced by Gunna’s frequent collaborators Taurus and Turbo, making the record 100% Atlantan.

The collaboration is meant for the soundtrack to Spiral, the latest instalment in the SAW series of horror movies. 21 Savage previewed the song’s intro on Instagram two days before its release.

songs.full_title: Come and Get Your Bitch by 21 Savage
songs.title: Come and Get Your Bitch

description.plain:
“Come and Get Your Bitch” is an unreleased track from artist, 21 Savage. On the Pi'erre Bourne-produced track, 21 raps about his problems with women following him as a consequence of his fame.

The track was first first previewed on a file-sharing website on the August 11, 2019 and leaked one week later on August 18, 2019. It is unknown if the track will ever make an official appearance on any of 21 Savage’s upcoming albums.

songs.title: Start Dying

description.plain:
21 Savage and Offset take their Atlanta attitude and aggression to create a classic Trap and straight out the cut vibe. Offset’s Gwinett County origins combined with 21’s Zone 6 roots create a true Atlanta sound.

Start Dying can be considered the retrofit foreshadowing of Without Warning, which was a full-length album between Offset, 21 Savage, and producer Metro Boomin released on October 31, 2017.

songs.title: Baby Choppa

description.plain:
“Baby Choppa” is an unreleased collaboration between Atlanta rapper 21 Savage and New York-based producer Pi'erre Bourne.

Recorded in early 2017, it was later previewed by 21 via Instagram, but it never saw an official release. It was sold by Music Mafia in mid-2018.

The track finally surfaced on April 20, 2019, via Strapped Entertainment.

As a result of the track being a throwaway, Pi'erre Bourne gave the instrumental to Reese LAFLARE for “Cash Talk.”

songs.title: Big Facts

description.plain:
On “Big Facts,” Atlanta rapper 21 Savage affirms his authenticity and boasts about his privileged lifestyle. 21 further flexes his gang affiliations and warns his opposition of his murderous capabilities, while also bragging about his expensive materials.

The track was leaked on August 12th, 2019.

songs.full_title: Issa (Single Mix) by 21 Savage (Ft. Drake & Young Thug)
songs.title: Issa (Single Mix)

description.plain:
“Issa” is an unreleased collaboration between 21 Savage, Young Thug and Drake intended for Issa Album, however, various leaks stopped it from ever being released. This is a shorter and mastered version that leaked online on June 17, 2019.

According to the person who leaked the track, though it’s shorter, this version is likely closer to what would appear on the album than previous versions. Differences include: the lack of 21’s extra verses; the lack of some adlibs on Thug’s verse as well as his outro, and cleaner mixing on his vocals; and Drake’s verses being combined leading to a more linear structure.

songs.title: Hold Up

description.plain:
“Hold Up” is an unreleased song by rapper 21 Savage, produced by frequent-collaborator Metro Boomin and Southside.

The song was leaked by Music Mafia on April 20, 2018. Its origins are unknown, though it’s possible that it was recorded during the Savage Mode or Issa Album sessions.

songs.title: Moonrock

description.plain: “Moonrock” is an unreleased collaboration between 21 Savage and Southside; its title refers to highly potent marijuana that tends to have a THC level of around 50%. The track was teased by Southside in September 2016, however, it never saw an official release. It leaked online on March 27, 2020.

The track was teased by Southside in September 2016, however, it never saw an official release. It leaked online on March 27, 2020.

songs.title: Ass Thang

description.plain:
“Ass Thang” is a leaked collaboration between 21 Savage and Metro Boomin.

Details about the song are largely unknown, however, it’s possible that it was recorded during sessions for Savage Mode.

The song was first teased by Music Mafia when they put a snippet of the song up for sale. The full song leaked online on July 14, 2018.

songs.full_title: Whole Lot (Demo) by 21 Savage (Ft. Young Thug)
songs.title: Whole Lot (Demo)

description.plain:
“Whole Lot” appears on 21 Savage’s debut, Issa Album. This, however, is an early demo version of the song featuring Young Thug.

This early version of the song combines both of 21 Savage’s verses from the final version, along with a lengthy verse from Thugger who only provided ad-libs on the final cut.

The song was leaked by Music Mafia on May 30, 2018.

songs.title: Scared Now

description.plain: “Scared Now” is the original title of what would become 21 Savage’s “7 Min Freestyle” from his debut album, Issa Album. Notable differences include a different intro and a different structure to the song; it appears that this version was created from the original freestyle, but 21 decided to to release the freestyle instead. The song leaked online on June 19, 2019.

songs.title: Backpack*

description.plain:
This track, along with Issa album cut “7 Min Freestyle” were teased on producer Metro Boomin’s Instagram story late March of 2017. It was assumed that “Backpack” would appear on Issa but it didn’t make the cut. Although a sequel was never confirmed, The FADER magazine reported that the duo had recorded 20-30 more records, some of which possibly landed on Issa. Metro helped on the production on 8 of the 14-track album.

The track shows your average 21 Savage, detailing the trap life, gun violence and drug dealing that makes him the savage he is.

songs.title: Shit Talk

description.plain:
“Shit Talk”, previously known by fans as “Stingy” or “Big Dawg Status” is an unreleased track by 21 Savage produced by London on da Track.

The song was recorded in 2019, and a snippet of the track surfaced on a file-sharing website.

The song leaked in its entirety on December 6, 2022.

songs.title: Tom Ford*

description.plain:
“Tom Ford” is the speculative title for a currently-unreleased song by 21 Savage. Judging by the sound and tone of the instrumental, it’s possible that it was left off of Savage’s collaborative tape with Offset and Metro Boomin, Without Warning.

This snippet was leaked when Music Mafia attempted to auction the song in January 2018.

songs.title: Gun Sound (Demo)

description.plain:
Pi'erre Bourne first previewed this track in early 2017 on an IG live along with another collaboration with 21 Savage and “One Day” by Playboi Carti.
We would hear nothing from this song at all until late 2017 where Pi'erre would yet again play a snippet of the song but this time it was extended.
After that we would go almost 3 years without hearing this song at all until late 2019 a random CDQ snippet of the song would surface.
Then somewhere in 2020 another CDQ snippet would surface with a different part of the song.
Song is obviously a throwaway and is unknown if it will even leak.

songs.title: All My Niggas*

description.plain:
“All My Niggas” is a collaboration between 21 Savage and Pi'erre Bourne that was recorded sometime in 2017.

The first time we would hear this song would be on December 15, 2017 on Pi'erre’s Instagram live. He also previewed another 21 Savage collaboration called “Gun Sound” and “One Day” by Playboi Carti.

We wouldn’t hear anything from this song until sometime in January of 20121 where a cdq snippet of the song surfaced. Meaning the song was getting sold.

This song is most likely from the collaboration tape 21 Savage and Pi'erre Bourne had coming but never dropped.

songs.title: Watch That*

description.plain:
“Watch That” is a very unknown track that was most likely recorded sometime in 2017.

We wouldn’t even know this track existed until early 2019 when famous music leaking group “Music Mafia” leaked a cdq snippet of the song.

The track uses the same beat as SG Tip’s “Looking For me”.

songs.title: Side Bitch*

description.plain:
“Side Bitch” is a collaboration between 21 Savage and Pi'erre Bourne.

This song was previewed very briefly by Pi'erre in an Instagram live in late 2017. Pi'erre also previewed another 21 Savage collaboration called “Gun Sound”, “Extendo” by Young Nudy and “Bands Up” by Playboi Carti.

We wouldn’t hear anything about this song until a cdq snippet of the song surfaced sometime in January of 2021.
